info: Microsoft filed as a large accelerated filer for FY2025, reporting a non‑affiliate market value of $3.1 trillion and 7.43 billion shares outstanding; the company highlighted its AI‑driven cloud strategy, recent segment realignment into Productivity & Business Processes, Intelligent Cloud and More Personal Computing, and ongoing sustainability commitments.

The company reorganized its operating segments in August 2024, moving Microsoft 365 commercial components into the Productivity and Business Processes segment, with the new reporting structure effective FY2025. It highlighted growth drivers across its segments—AI‑enabled Microsoft 365, LinkedIn engagement, Dynamics cloud adoption, Azure AI and hybrid cloud services, Windows OEM licensing, Surface devices, Xbox gaming subscriptions, and Bing/Edge advertising—while noting competitive pressures in each area. Human capital stands at roughly 228,000 employees as of June 30, 2025, with detailed headcounts by region and function, underscoring the scale of its workforce supporting operations, R&D, sales, and administration.

Microsoft highlights its diversified go‑to‑market model—including direct sales, distributors, VARs, OEMs and cloud partner programs—while noting that licenses are typically obtained on commercially reasonable terms and not dependent on any single third‑party agreement. The company emphasizes ongoing AI and cloud investments, acknowledging intense competitive pressures and execution risks that could affect margins. It outlines comprehensive regulatory compliance efforts across global jurisdictions. Executive leadership as of July 30 2025 is listed with ages and tenure, reflecting stable senior management.

The company highlights significant risks to its cloud and AI strategy, including competitive pressure, high infrastructure costs, and uncertainty over revenue growth, as well as potential misuse of its services and extensive cybersecurity threats that could harm reputation and financial results. It also notes integration and goodwill impairment risks from recent acquisitions, such as the Activision Blizzard deal, and regulatory and platform‑abuse challenges that may increase costs and affect user engagement.

The filing highlights extensive risks including content moderation liabilities, AI regulatory and ethical challenges, operational vulnerabilities such as data center outages and supply chain constraints, software and hardware quality issues, broad legal and regulatory exposure (antitrust, AI Act, anti‑corruption, trade sanctions, cybersecurity, data privacy, ESG), significant tax audit where the IRS seeks an additional $28.9 billion, intellectual‑property infringement and source‑code protection risks, and potential reputation damage from product or policy missteps, all of which could materially affect financial performance.

The filing highlights a broad set of material risks including reputation damage, economic downturns, geopolitical instability, and cybersecurity threats, while emphasizing the company's extensive cybersecurity program (Secure Future Initiative) that monitors 84 trillion daily signals, tracks over 1,500 threat actors and employs more than 10,000 security experts. It also outlines the sizable global real‑estate footprint of roughly 97 million square feet (15 million in the U.S. headquarters alone) and ongoing share repurchase activity in Q2 2025 totaling about 7.5 million shares, with an average price near $400 per share, and notes 77,014 registered shareholders.

Board authorized a $60 billion share repurchase program and returned $9.4 billion to shareholders in Q4 FY2025 via buybacks and a $0.83 per‑share dividend ($6.17 billion total). In May 2025 the company issued 117,623 shares for an acquisition. Revenue rose 15% to $281.7 billion, driven by 23% cloud growth to $168.9 billion, while gross margin grew 13% but margin percentage slipped due to AI infrastructure spending. Operating income and net income rose 17% and 16% respectively, lifting diluted EPS to $13.64. Higher operating expenses reflect continued investment in cloud, AI and gaming.

Revenue grew 15% to $281.724 B in FY2025 with segment gains across Productivity (up 13% to $120.81 B), Intelligent Cloud (up 21% to $106.27 B) and More Personal Computing (up 7% to $54.65 B). Operating income rose 17% to $128.53 B; gross margin increased $22.9 B though margin percentage slipped, with Microsoft Cloud gross margin at 69%. Operating expenses rose 6% to $65.37 B, driven by higher cloud and AI investments. R&D spending rose 10% to $32.49 B, sales and marketing up 5% to $25.65 B, while G&A fell 5% to $7.22 B. Effective tax rate remained 18%; U.S. pre‑tax income was $69.2 B and foreign $54.4 B. Other income turned more negative, with net other loss of $4.9 B. The company disclosed an ongoing IRS audit seeking an additional $28.9 B adjustment, though no material impact is expected in the next year.

Microsoft notes ongoing IRS audits with a $28.9 billion proposed adjustment, monitors OECD Pillar Two (15% minimum tax) and the new OBBBA 14% rate, but expects no material impact on its statements. Cash and short‑term investments remain robust at $94.6 billion, with operating cash flow rising to $136.2 billion and share repurchases and dividends continuing at multi‑billion levels. The company outlines unearned revenue schedules totaling $67.3 billion and sizable contractual obligations exceeding $397 billion, while transition tax installments and other capital commitments are being managed.

The filing highlights material legal and tax uncertainties that could affect financial statements, and outlines market risk exposures to foreign currency, interest rates, credit spreads and equity price declines with quantified potential earnings and fair‑value impacts. Sensitivity analysis shows possible losses ranging from $5 million to $11.6 billion under adverse scenarios. Financial results show total revenue of $281.7 billion in 2025 up from $245.1 billion in 2024, and net income of $101.8 billion, reflecting continued growth and improving profitability across product and service segments.

Total assets grew to 619,003 million in 2025 from 512,163 million in 2024, supported by higher cash and short‑term investments and increased property‑and‑equipment. Cash and cash equivalents rose 65% YoY to 30,242 million, while total equity increased to 343,479 million, driven by higher retained earnings and modest share issuances. Net income rose 15% to 101,832 million in 2025 and operating cash flow remained robust at 136,162 million. Financing activities produced a net cash outflow of 51,699 million, chiefly from stock repurchases and dividends, and investing activities used 72,599 million, reflecting continued capital expenditures and acquisitions. The firm’s liquidity improved despite sizable debt and lease liabilities.

Stockholders’ equity rose markedly, with total equity reaching 343479 million in 2025 versus 206223 million in 2023, supported by higher net income, increased cash dividends per share (3.32 vs 2.72) and continued share repurchases. Stock‑based compensation expense grew each year, reaching 11974 million in 2025. Advertising expense accelerated to 2100 million in 2025. Long‑term accounts receivable and other receivables grew, while financing receivables remained near 4.3‑4.5 billion.

The company reported net income of $101.8B, $88.1B and $72.4B for 2025‑2023 respectively, with basic EPS rising to $13.70 in 2025 from $9.72 in 2023. Weighted shares remained stable around 7.4B. Other income was a net loss of $4.9B in 2025 after a $0.8B gain in 2023, driven by interest expense, derivative losses and investment impairments. Debt investment activity generated modest realized gains but larger losses and impairments, yielding a net -$17B in 2025. Equity investment activity showed strong unrealized gains ($536B in 2025) offset by $951B impairments, resulting in a net -$332B for 2025. The firm reaffirmed a $13B funding commitment to OpenAI and highlighted ongoing accounting updates and related‑party licensing arrangements.

Net gains on equity investments were positive in 2023 ($358 million) but negative in 2024 ($65 million) and 2025 ($332 million) due to sizable impairments ($229 million in 2024, $951 million in 2025). Realized gains from sales were modest ($75 million in 2023, $18 million in 2024, $83 million in 2025) while unrealized gains on held securities remained sizable but fell each year (303 million in 2023 to 146 million in 2024 to 536 million in 2025). The company’s investment portfolio is dominated by debt securities (≈$85.6 billion adjusted cost basis) with a $11.7 billion cash position and $28.4 billion in short‑term holdings; equity investments total about $13.7 billion. Derivatives have a small net exposure. Overall, the firm reports a net loss on investments for 2024 and 2025, offset by a gain in 2023.

Debt investment portfolio shows $68.2 b total fair value (June 2024) with $3.3 b unrealized losses; cash $11.6 b and derivatives $12 m. Equity investments without readily determinable fair values fell to $2.9 b in 2025 from $3.9 b in 2024, while equity‑method holdings remained $6.0 b. June 2025 debt holdings exhibit $4.56 b fair value for positions held <12 months with $65 m unrealized loss, and $38.176 b fair value for >12 months with $1.56 b loss, totaling $42.736 b fair value and $1.625 b cumulative loss.

Unrealized losses of $3.3bn on fixed‑income securities were driven by rising interest rates, with total fair value of $54.6bn as of June 30 2024. Debt investments of $85.6bn (cost) are weighted toward short‑term maturities, with $35.1bn due within one year and fair value $35.0bn. Derivative activity is sizable: designated hedging contracts total $1.5bn notional, while non‑designated contracts exceed $100bn, including $43.3bn of foreign‑exchange contracts sold. Net derivative assets are $500m versus $1.676bn liabilities in 2025, improving from $180m vs $752m in 2024. Netting agreements offset $452m of assets against $1.8bn liabilities in 2025. Management notes no impairments on unrealized losses and maintains AAA rating and $1bn liquidity.

Derivative gains were modest with a $5 million gain in 2025 versus losses in prior years; non‑designated FX contracts incurred a $938 million loss in 2025. Property, plant and equipment net value rose to $205 billion in 2025, driven by higher land and equipment holdings. Depreciation expense increased sharply to $22 billion in 2025. The company completed the $75.4 billion Activision Blizzard acquisition, adding $51 billion of goodwill and $22 billion of intangible assets, and reported pro‑forma revenue of $247 billion for 2024. No goodwill impairments were recorded, with accumulated impairment remaining at $11.3 billion.

The company reported no intangible asset impairments for FY2023‑2025 and listed component amounts totaling $1.1 bn, with amortization expense rising to $6.0 bn in 2025. Future amortization of $22.6 bn is scheduled through 2030 and thereafter. Short‑term commercial paper was $0 in 2025 versus $6.7 bn in 2024. Long‑term debt face value declined to $49.2 bn in 2025, with net long‑term debt $40.2 bn and fair value $40.4 bn; total debt $43.2 bn. Interest cash paid was $1.6 bn in 2025. Income tax provision increased to $21.8 bn, with current tax $28.9 bn and deferred tax $‑7.1 bn. Pre‑tax earnings rose to $123.6 bn in 2025.

Effective tax rate fell from 19.0% in 2023 to 17.6% in 2025 as foreign earnings taxed at lower Irish rates (81-83% of foreign income) and tax law changes provided credits. The company carries large federal, state and foreign net operating loss carryforwards ($390M, $836M, $2.6B) and $816M federal capital loss carryforwards. Income taxes paid were $28.7B in 2025. Unrecognized tax benefits remain sizable ($24.7B ending 2025) and the IRS audit for 2004-2013 seeks an additional $28.9B plus penalties, which the company will contest. Deferred tax assets net rose to $45.9B in 2025, while deferred tax liabilities were $19.7B. Unearned revenue increased to $67.3B in 2025, driven by higher productivity and business processes balances. Remaining performance obligations total $375B, with $368B attributed to commercial revenue.

The company reported a substantial unearned revenue balance of $60.2 billion at the start of the period, increasing to $67.3 billion by year‑end after a $186.9 billion deferral and $179.9 billion recognition. Total remaining performance obligations are $375 billion (commercial $368 billion) with about 40% expected to be recognized in the next 12 months. Lease expenses remain significant, with operating lease costs of $5.5 billion in 2025 and total finance lease costs of $4.8 billion. Lease liabilities total $22.9 billion (operating) and $46.2 billion (finance) at year‑end, with additional upcoming leases of $92.7 billion slated to commence 2026‑2031. Legal contingencies include accrued liabilities of $541 million and possible adverse outcomes up to $600 million. A GDPR‑related investigation continues with an appeal pending. Share repurchase programs total $60 billion authorized, $57.3 billion remaining, and $13 billion repurchased in 2025.

Company used cash for share repurchases, noting tax withholding settlements of $5.4B, $5.3B and $3.8B for FY2025‑23. Declared quarterly dividends of $0.83 per share in FY2025 and $0.75 in FY2024, totalling $24.678B and $22.295B respectively. Accumulated other comprehensive loss increased to $3.347B (2025) driven by derivative and investment unrealized gains/losses. Stock‑based compensation expense rose to $11.974B in FY2025 with $2.027B tax benefits. Stock‑award activity showed 39M new awards, 38M vested and 7M forfeited, leaving 82M non‑vested shares; unrecognized compensation cost stands at $21.6B. ESPP purchases were 6M, 6M and 7M shares in FY2025‑23 at average prices of $385.10, $339.46 and $245.59, with 62M shares reserved for future issuance.

The ESPP saw 6‑7 million shares purchased in each recent year at average prices of $385.10 (2025), $339.46 (2024) and $245.59 (2023) with 62 million shares reserved, while employer‑funded retirement benefits grew to $1.8 b in FY2025; segment operating income rose across Productivity & Business Processes, Intelligent Cloud and More Personal Computing, driving total operating income to $128.5 b and total revenue to $281.7 b in FY2025, led by Server and cloud services ($98.4 b) and Microsoft 365 Commercial ($87.8 b), U.S. revenue reached $144.5 b versus $137.2 b elsewhere, no customer exceeded 10% of revenue, Microsoft Cloud revenue hit $168.9 b, and long‑lived assets increased to $371.9 b.

Auditor Deloitte & Touche issued unqualified opinions on Microsoft’s 2025 and 2024 financial statements and internal control over financial reporting as of June 30, 2025, confirming material accuracy and effective controls. The audit highlighted extensive procedures on revenue recognition judgments and uncertain tax positions, noting ongoing IRS audits for transfer‑pricing adjustments covering tax years 2004‑2013 that could materially affect results. The filing also references several outstanding debt instruments with interest rates ranging from 0.875% to 5.20% and notes that Deloitte has been Microsoft’s auditor since 1983.

The filing lists a series of supplemental indentures for Microsoft’s senior notes, detailing multiple issuances from 2011 to 2023 with interest rates ranging from 0.875% to 5.300% and maturities extending through 2062, reflecting continuous debt financing activity.
The filing lists numerous supplemental indenture, compensation plan and governance exhibits and includes the corporate signature dated July 30, 2025.
